title: Custom Draft - 2025-05-22 21:54

sections.title: Cover Sheet
sections.description: Basic information about the applicant organization and the grant request.

questions.text: Date of Application
questions.sample_answer: October 26, 2023

questions.text: Legal Name of Organization Applying
questions.sample_answer: Community Support Network Inc.

questions.text: Year Founded
Current Annual Operating Budget
Are you currently receiving United Way Program Funding? Identify programs and amount:
questions.sample_answer: Yes. We currently receive $25,000 annually for our Youth Mentoring Program and $10,000 for our Senior Citizen Support Services.

questions.text: Executive Director
questions.sample_answer: Jane Doe

questions.text: Contact Person/Title (if different from Executive Director)
questions.sample_answer: John Smith, Program Manager

questions.text: Address (principal/administrative office)
questions.sample_answer: 123 Main Street, Suite 400

questions.text: Mailing Address, if different from above
questions.sample_answer: Same as above

questions.text: City, State, Zip
questions.sample_answer: Anytown, CA 91234

questions.text: Phone Number
Fax Number
Project Name
questions.sample_answer: Community Garden Initiative

questions.text: Purpose of Grant (one sentence)
questions.sample_answer: To establish a community garden to increase access to fresh produce and foster community engagement.

questions.text: Beginning and Ending Dates of the Project/Campaign
questions.sample_answer: January 1, 2024 - December 31, 2024

questions.text: Amount Requested
Total Project Cost
Geographic Area Served
questions.sample_answer: Anytown, CA

sections.title: Narrative
sections.description: Detailed description of the organization, the proposed project, and the evaluation plan.

questions.text: Summarize your organization’s history.
questions.sample_answer: Community Support Network Inc. (CSN) was founded in 1998 with a mission to improve the well-being of residents in Anytown, CA.  Initially focusing on youth outreach, CSN expanded its services over the years to encompass various community needs. Our programs have consistently demonstrated positive impact through measurable outcomes and community feedback. We pride ourselves on fostering strong partnerships with local organizations.

questions.text: State your mission and goals, future challenges, and long-range plans.
questions.sample_answer: Our mission is to empower individuals and strengthen communities through collaborative action and sustainable initiatives. Our key goals include increasing access to resources for underserved populations, promoting community engagement and fostering social equity. Future challenges include securing consistent funding and adapting to changing community needs. Our long-range plans involve establishing a comprehensive network of support systems that address the holistic needs of Anytown residents.

questions.text: Outline current programs and activities.
questions.sample_answer: Currently, CSN runs several successful programs, including youth mentoring, senior citizen support services, and educational workshops. These programs offer a wide range of resources and support, helping individuals overcome barriers and thrive in their community. The programs are carefully designed to address specific needs and measurable outcomes are tracked to ensure efficacy.

questions.text: Highlight accomplishments.
questions.sample_answer: CSN has achieved significant accomplishments over the past 25 years.  We have successfully mentored over 500 youth, provided essential support to hundreds of senior citizens, and conducted numerous educational workshops that have empowered community members.  Our programs have consistently received positive feedback, indicating a strong positive impact on the community.

questions.text: Differentiate yourself from similar or competing organizations.
questions.sample_answer: Unlike other organizations in Anytown, CSN emphasizes a holistic approach, addressing multiple community needs simultaneously. Our strong community partnerships and commitment to collaborative initiatives ensure that our services are well-integrated and maximize their impact. Furthermore, our evidence-based programming ensures we are providing effective and needed services to the community.

questions.text: Describe the proposed program or project.
questions.sample_answer: The Community Garden Initiative aims to create a vibrant community garden that provides fresh produce to low-income families and fosters a sense of community ownership and engagement. The garden will be located on a vacant city-owned plot and will be managed by volunteers and community members.  We will partner with local schools and community groups to implement educational programs focusing on sustainable agriculture and healthy eating.

questions.text: Identify the needs/problems to be addressed, target population and number of people to be served by the project.
questions.sample_answer: This project addresses the lack of access to fresh, healthy food in low-income neighborhoods.  Our target population is families with children under the age of 18 living in designated low-income areas of Anytown, representing approximately 500 individuals. We aim to directly serve at least 200 families through the distribution of produce grown in the garden.

questions.text: Describe the project goals and objectives, and your plan to meet them.
questions.sample_answer: Our main goal is to improve access to fresh produce for low-income families.  We will achieve this by establishing and maintaining a community garden, providing educational workshops on gardening and healthy eating, and distributing fresh produce to the community. To ensure success, we will partner with local organizations, recruit volunteers, and implement a sustainable gardening plan.

questions.text: Define the project as a new or continuing program.
questions.sample_answer: New

questions.text: Identify other organizations, partners or funders participating in the project and their roles.
questions.sample_answer: We are collaborating with Anytown Parks and Recreation Department who will provide the land for the garden and support with infrastructure development. We are also partnering with the local school district, who will support educational programs related to the garden and assist with volunteer recruitment.  Additionally, we have applied for a matching grant from the Anytown Community Foundation.

questions.text: Provide a timetable for implementation.
questions.sample_answer: The project will be implemented over a 12-month period.  Months 1-3 will focus on land preparation, planting, and volunteer recruitment. Months 4-9 will be dedicated to garden maintenance and educational workshops. Months 10-12 will focus on harvesting and distribution of produce, along with project evaluation.

questions.text: Identify long-term funding resources.
questions.sample_answer: Long-term funding will be pursued through a combination of grants, corporate sponsorships, and fundraising events. We will also explore the possibility of establishing a community support fund to ensure the garden’s sustainability beyond the initial grant period.  We plan to apply for ongoing grants from various foundations and explore potential partnerships with local businesses.

questions.text: If a similar program or service has been conducted by your organization or another, please discuss its impact. Does it represent an expansion or duplication of services in your area? If it doesn’t, define its potential to serve as a model program locally or nationally.
questions.sample_answer: This is a new program for CSN.  We believe this project has the potential to serve as a model program locally and potentially nationally due to its unique integration of food security, community engagement, and educational outreach. The success of this program could inspire other organizations to implement similar initiatives to address food deserts and improve community well-being.

questions.text: Describe your plan to document progress and results.
questions.sample_answer: We will track project progress and results through regular monitoring of garden productivity, volunteer participation rates, community engagement activities, and the number of families served. We will also conduct pre- and post-program surveys to assess the impact on participants' access to fresh produce and their overall well-being.  Quarterly progress reports will be submitted to the granting organization, with a comprehensive final report detailing all outcomes and financial expenditures upon project completion.

sections.title: Attachments
sections.description: Supporting documents required for the grant application.

questions.text: Copy of the current IRS determination letter indicating 501(c)(3) tax-exempt status.
questions.sample_answer: Attached

questions.text: Statement verifying payroll tax payments.
questions.sample_answer: Attached

questions.text: Organizational structure, including: List of officers and directors, including occupations, places of employment, and relevant affiliations. Description of board responsibilities, including committee assignments. Resumes and/or job descriptions of key personnel involved in the project.
questions.sample_answer: Attached

questions.text: Finances, including: Grant budget. List of other funders, potential funders and amounts committed or requested, including public contracts, individual contributions and other sources of income supporting the project. Current board-approved annual operating budget, including expenses and income. Most recent audited annual financial statement. Letters of support (optional) that substantiate need for the project and collaboration with other organizations. Annual report, if available.
questions.sample_answer: Attached

sections.title: Budget
sections.description: Detailed breakdown of project expenses and income.

questions.text: Please specify the budget period (e.g., January 1, 2024 to December 31, 2024).
questions.sample_answer: January 1, 2024 to December 31, 2024

questions.text: Please itemize the following expenses. Be sure to include any additional items relevant to your particular program. Provide an expense total.
questions.sample_answer:
The following is a detailed itemization of the expenses:

Salaries and Wages: $10,000
Payroll Taxes: $1,000
Fringe Benefits: $500
Consultant Fees: $2,000
Supplies: $3,000
Equipment: $5,000
Rent: $1,000
Utilities: $500
In-Kind Expenses (Volunteer Time): $2,000
Total Expenses: $25,000

questions.text: Please include all confirmed and anticipated sources of revenue, and indicate their status. Provide an income total.
questions.sample_answer:
The following is a detailed itemization of the anticipated income sources:

Grant Funding Requested: $25,000
Matching Grant (Anytown Community Foundation): $25,000
Total Income: $50,000

sections.title: Capital Campaign Narrative (If Applicable)
sections.description: Detailed description of the capital campaign, including goals, objectives, and evaluation plan.

questions.text: Describe the proposed campaign, including goals and objectives.
questions.sample_answer: This capital campaign aims to raise $1 million to construct a new community center that will house a variety of programs and services for Anytown residents. The primary objective is to create a central hub for community activities and provide much needed facilities to enhance community well-being.

questions.text: Identify the need/problem to be addressed, target population and number of people to be served by the project.
questions.sample_answer: The current lack of adequate facilities for community activities and programs serves as the primary need addressed by this capital campaign.  The target population is the broad population of Anytown residents which include diverse demographics such as children, adults, and senior citizens. This facility would provide opportunities for several thousand individuals.

questions.text: Provide a timetable for implementation and completion.
questions.sample_answer: The capital campaign will span 18 months, with phase one (6 months) focused on fundraising and securing major donations. Phase two (12 months) will involve construction and facility development. This timeline allows for efficient resource allocation and facilitates timely project completion.

questions.text: List the campaign leadership, their strengths and affiliations.
questions.sample_answer: The campaign leadership includes Jane Doe, Executive Director (proven fundraising experience), John Smith, Board Chair (strong community ties), and Sarah Jones, Development Officer (expertise in grant writing). Their collective strengths and diverse affiliations will be crucial in driving the campaign's success.

questions.text: Describe your plan to document progress and results.
questions.sample_answer: We will meticulously track the campaign's progress using a comprehensive system of metrics.  Regular reports will be generated and shared with stakeholders highlighting achievements, challenges faced, and strategies for improvement. A final evaluation will be conducted after the completion of the construction, assessing the facility's impact on the community and attainment of stated objectives.

generated_content:
```html Community Garden Initiative Grant Proposal

Community Garden Initiative Grant Proposal

Cover Sheet

Date of Application: October 26, 2023

Legal Name of Organization Applying: Community Support Network Inc. (CSN)

Year Founded: 1998

Current Annual Operating Budget: $500,000

United Way Program Funding: Yes. $25,000 annually for our Youth Mentoring Program and $10,000 for our Senior Citizen Support Services.

Executive Director: Jane Doe

Contact Person/Title: John Smith, Program Manager

Address: 123 Main Street, Suite 400, Anytown, CA 91234

Phone Number: (555) 123-4567

Fax Number: (555) 123-4568

Project Name: Community Garden Initiative

Purpose of Grant: To establish a community garden to increase access to fresh produce and foster community engagement in Anytown, CA.

Beginning and Ending Dates of the Project: January 1, 2024 - December 31, 2024

Amount Requested: $25,000

Total Project Cost: $50,000

Geographic Area Served: Anytown, CA

Narrative

Organization History and Mission

Community Support Network Inc. (CSN) was founded in 1998 with a mission to improve the well-being of Anytown residents. Starting with youth outreach, CSN expanded to address diverse community needs. Our consistent track record of positive impact, demonstrated through measurable outcomes and community feedback, showcases our commitment to excellence. We value strong partnerships and collaborative initiatives.

Mission, Goals, and Future Plans

Our mission is to empower individuals and strengthen communities through collaborative action and sustainable initiatives. Key goals include increasing resource access for underserved populations, promoting community engagement, and fostering social equity. Future challenges include securing consistent funding and adapting to evolving community needs. Our long-range plan involves building a comprehensive support network addressing the holistic needs of Anytown residents.

Current Programs and Activities

CSN currently operates successful programs including youth mentoring (serving over 500 youth), senior citizen support services (supporting hundreds of seniors), and educational workshops (empowering numerous community members). These programs are designed to meet specific needs, and we meticulously track measurable outcomes to ensure efficacy.

Accomplishments and Differentiation

Over 25 years, CSN has achieved significant accomplishments, including mentoring over 500 youth and providing essential support to hundreds of senior citizens. Positive community feedback consistently validates our positive impact. Unlike other organizations, CSN utilizes a holistic approach, addressing multiple needs simultaneously. Our strong community partnerships and commitment to collaboration maximize our services’ impact. Our evidence-based programming ensures we deliver effective and necessary services.

Proposed Program: Community Garden Initiative

The Community Garden Initiative will create a vibrant community garden providing fresh produce to low-income families and fostering community engagement. Located on a vacant city-owned plot, the garden will be managed by volunteers and community members. Partnerships with local schools and community groups will facilitate educational programs on sustainable agriculture and healthy eating.

Needs Addressed and Target Population

This project tackles the lack of access to fresh, healthy food in low-income neighborhoods. Our target population is families with children under 18 in designated low-income areas of Anytown (approximately 500 individuals). We aim to directly serve at least 200 families through produce distribution.

Project Goals, Objectives, and Plan

Our main goal is improved access to fresh produce for low-income families. This will be achieved through garden establishment and maintenance, educational workshops, and produce distribution. Success will be ensured through partnerships, volunteer recruitment, and a sustainable gardening plan. We will track the number of families served, pounds of produce harvested, and volunteer hours contributed.

Program Type and Partnerships

This is a new program. We are collaborating with the Anytown Parks and Recreation Department (land and infrastructure), the local school district (educational programs and volunteer recruitment), and the Anytown Community Foundation (matching grant).

Implementation Timetable

  • Months 1-3: Land preparation, planting, volunteer recruitment.
  • Months 4-9: Garden maintenance, educational workshops.
  • Months 10-12: Harvesting, distribution, project evaluation.

Long-Term Funding

Long-term funding will be pursued through grants, corporate sponsorships, fundraising events, and a potential community support fund. We plan to apply for ongoing grants and explore business partnerships.

Program Impact and Potential

This new program has the potential to serve as a model locally and nationally due to its integration of food security, community engagement, and educational outreach. Its success could inspire similar initiatives nationwide.

Progress and Results Documentation

Project progress will be tracked through monitoring garden productivity, volunteer participation, community engagement activities, and the number of families served. Pre- and post-program surveys will assess impact on participants’ access to fresh produce and well-being. Quarterly reports will be submitted, with a comprehensive final report upon completion.

Attachments

The following attachments are provided:

  • Copy of the current IRS determination letter indicating 501(c)(3) tax-exempt status.
  • Statement verifying payroll tax payments.
  • Organizational structure, including: List of officers and directors, their occupations, places of employment, relevant affiliations, board responsibilities (including committee assignments), resumes/job descriptions of key personnel involved in the project.
  • Finances, including: Grant budget, list of other funders/potential funders and amounts, current board-approved annual operating budget, most recent audited annual financial statement, letters of support, annual report.

Budget

Budget Period: January 1, 2024 to December 31, 2024

Expense Item Amount
Salaries and Wages $10,000
Payroll Taxes $1,000
Fringe Benefits $500
Consultant Fees (Gardening Expert) $2,000
Supplies (seeds, tools, fertilizers) $3,000
Equipment (watering system, tools) $5,000
Rent (tool shed, if needed) $1,000
Utilities (water) $500
In-Kind Expenses (Volunteer Time - estimated value) $2,000
Total Expenses $25,000
Income Source Amount Status
Grant Funding Requested $25,000 Requested
Matching Grant (Anytown Community Foundation) $25,000 Applied For
Total Income $50,000

Capital Campaign Narrative (Separate Project)

Proposed Campaign: New Community Center

This capital campaign aims to raise $1 million to construct a new community center housing various programs and services. The objective is to create a central hub for community activities and enhance community well-being. This will allow us to expand our services and better serve the Anytown community.

Needs Addressed and Target Population

The campaign addresses the lack of adequate facilities for community activities. The target population is all Anytown residents (several thousand individuals).

Implementation Timetable

  • Phase 1 (6 months): Fundraising and securing major donations.
  • Phase 2 (12 months): Construction and facility development.

Campaign Leadership

The campaign leadership includes Jane Doe (Executive Director, fundraising experience), John Smith (Board Chair, strong community ties), and Sarah Jones (Development Officer, grant writing expertise). Their combined skills and connections will drive the campaign's success.

Progress and Results Documentation

Progress will be tracked using a comprehensive system of metrics. Regular reports will be shared with stakeholders, highlighting achievements, challenges, and strategies. A final evaluation will assess the facility’s impact and objective attainment post-construction.

```
